key_work.title: Giovanni Pastrone
key_work.brief_description: Giovanni Pastrone was a director, producer, actor and inventor who pioneered the use of diffused lighting, panoramas, grandiose sets, miniature models and a moving camera. All of these elements were on show in his epic 1914 film, Cabiria.

start.title: Phantom Ride
start.credit_line:
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection

Daniel Crooks is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery, Australia and Future Perfect, Singapore
start.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, colour and audio
start.brief_description: Daniel Crooks’ Phantom Ride alludes to cinema history to create a seamless journey through a composite reality. By manipulating digital footage as though it were a physical material, Crooks has constructed a collaged landscape, taking us through multiple worlds and shifting our perception of space and time.

constellations_primary.name: Taking it slow
constellations_primary.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

end.title: No Reason (2017)
end.brief_description: The film clip for Bonobo’s No Reason, directed by Oscar Hudson, explores the Japanese concept of Hikikomori – young Japanese people who become so overwhelmed by the pressures of life that they retreat to their bedrooms for years at a time.

constellations_other.name: Tracking cinema
constellations_other.description: A constellation looking at the evolution of the tracking / dolly shot.

links.description: Hudson’s video for Bonobo’s ‘No Reason’ contains similar framing motifs to Crook’s Phantom Ride, but was shot in a single take using custom-built sets and cameras.

end.title: Black Panther
end.creator_credit: Kevin Feige and David J. Grant
end.brief_description: After his father’s death, T’Challa (Chadwick Boseman) returns home to Wakanda to inherit his throne and the mantle of the Black Panther. However, a powerful enemy related to his family threatens his nation and life in Marvel’s cinematic blockbuster.

constellations_other.name: Tracking cinema
constellations_other.description: A constellation looking at the evolution of the tracking / dolly shot.

links.description: Contrasting to Hudson’s use of a single tiny camera and customised sets, DoP Rachel Morrison utilised high-tech ‘descender’ rigs - cameras mounted on wires - and clever edits for the iconic multi-story tracking shot of a fight in Black Panther.

end.title: Cabiria
end.brief_description: Cabiria is a 1914 Italian epic silent film, directed by Giovanni Pastrone that laid the foundation for the Hollywood epics that followed. Featuring groundbreaking special effects used to show a volcanic eruption, the film is also famous for inventing the tracking shot.

end.title: Resident Evil 4
end.brief_description: An atmospheric survival horror game with inventive third-person shooting mechanics set six years after the events of Resident Evil 2 (1998), Resident Evil 4 follows Leon S. Kennedy, a former Raccoon City police officer sent to Spain on a secret mission.

constellations_other.name: Tracking cinema
constellations_other.description: A constellation looking at the evolution of the tracking / dolly shot.

links.description: Much as the camera follows behind Okoye in Black Panther‘s fight scene, Resident Evil 4 is one of the first games to employ a permanent ‘over the shoulder’ camera technique, turning much of the game into a digital tracking shot.

end.title: Russian Ark
end.creator_credit: NHK, YLE, Russian Ministry of Culture, Andrey Deryabin, Jens Meurer and Karsten Stöter
end.headline_credit: Canada, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Japan and Russia, 2002
end.brief_description: A 2002 experimental historical drama film by Alexander Sokurov features an unnamed narrator wandering through the Winter Palace in Saint Petersburg, who implies that he died in some horrible accident and is a ghost drifting through the corridors.

constellations_other.name: Tracking cinema
constellations_other.description: A constellation looking at the evolution of the tracking / dolly shot.

links.description: In Cabiria, Pastrone popularised the use of the tracking shot, creating a dolly to move the camera through a scene. One of the most ambitious use of this technique is Russian Ark, which is comprised of a single 96-minute tracking shot.
